results.name: A Seidel matrix A(n,k) read by antidiagonals upwards.
comment: The first row is a signed version of the Euler numbers A000111.
Other rows are defined by A(n+1,k) = A(n,k) + A(n,k+1).
link: Alois P. Heinz, Antidiagonals n = 0..140, flattened
A. Randrianarivony and J. Zeng, Une famille de polynomes qui interpole plusieurs suites classiques de nombres, Adv. Appl. Math. 17 (1996), 1-26. See Section 6 (matrix a_{n,k} on p. 18).
formula: Formulas about the square array A(n,k) (n,k > 0):
Formulas about the triangular array T(n,k) = A(n-k,k) (0 <= k <= n):
T(n,k) = Sum_{i=0..n-k} binomial(n-k,i)*T(k+i,k+i) for k=0..n with initial condition T(n,n) = (-1)^n*A163747(n). (End)
example: Triangular array T(n,k) = A(n-k,k) (n >= 0, k = 0..n), read from the antidiagonals upwards of square array A:
program: (PARI) {b(n) = local(v=[1], t); if( n<0, 0, for(k=2, n+2, t=0; v = vector(k, i, if( i>1, t+= v[k+1-i]))); v[2])}; \\ _Michael Somos_'s PARI program for A000111.
A(n, k) = sum(i=0, n, binomial(n, i)*c(k+i)) \\ _Petros Hadjicostas_, Mar 04 2021
xref: Cf. A000111, A002832 (next-to-main diagonal), A163747, A323834.
